elements.content: Photoluminescent lanthanide–organic frameworks (Ln-MOFs) were printed onto plastic and paper foils with a conventional inkjet printer. Ln-MOF inks were used to reproduce color images that can only be observed under UV light irradiation. This approach opens a new window for exploring Ln-MOF materials in technological applications, such as optical devices (e.g., lab-on-a-chip), as proof of authenticity for official documents.
elements.clean_text: Photoluminescent lanthanide-organic frameworks (Ln-MOFs) were printed onto plastic and paper foils with a conventional inkjet printer. Ln-MOF inks were used to reproduce color images that can only be observed under UV light irradiation. This approach opens a new window for exploring Ln-MOF materials in technological applications, such as optical devices (e.g., lab-on-a-chip), as proof of authenticity for official documents.

elements.content: New functional materials associated with innovative fabrication procedures are fostering technological developments of more specialized and sophisticated devices. In the past few years, high-technological sectors have explored magnetic, optical, size, and conducting properties of new materials and a diversity of processing techniques for the production of integrated circuits, smart textiles, batteries, solar cells, electroluminescent devices, sensors, and others. Most manufacturing processes use subtractive patterning methods and deposition of materials under high temperatures and ultravacuum conditions. Recent innovations in printing, roll-to-roll, and coating processes has generated some alternatives for the fabrication of customizable devices onto various substrates.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

New functional materials associated with innovative fabrication procedures are fostering technological developments of more specialized and sophisticated devices. In the past few years, high-technological sectors have explored magnetic, optical, size, and conducting properties of new materials and a diversity of processing techniques for the production of integrated circuits, smart textiles, batteries, solar cells, electroluminescent devices, sensors, and others. Most manufacturing processes use subtractive patterning methods and deposition of materials under high temperatures and ultravacuum conditions. Recent innovations in printing, roll-to-roll, and coating processes has generated some alternatives for the fabrication of customizable devices onto various substrates.

elements.content: In this context, coordination polymers (CPs) and metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have emerged as a versatile class and subclass of hybrid materials, which have attracted tremendous attention due to their intriguing structures, topological aspects, and potential for technological applications. Thousands of CPs and MOF structures have been systematically produced in the last two decades, and the net result is considerable progress regarding the controlled synthesis and production of specific functionalities and tunable properties. MOFs and CPs have been explored in important fields such as biomedicine, sensing, gas storage, separation, adsorption, drug delivery, forensic science, and catalysis. MOFs are also regarded as an excellent platform for the production of light-emissive materials because they offer a well-defined chemical environment for emitter centers and their hybrid character renders them with a diversity of optical phenomenon uncommon in classical light-emitting materials. Among the plethora of luminescent CPs and MOFs already reported, those based on lanthanide ions, that is lanthanide–organic frameworks (Ln-MOFs), are the most promising because they combine fairly interesting structuresa and thermodynamic stability with well-known magnetic behavior and spectroscopic properties originating from the lanthanide ions.
elements.clean_text: In this context, coordination polymers (CPs) and metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have emerged as a versatile class and subclass of hybrid materials, which have attracted tremendous attention due to their intriguing structures, topological aspects, and potential for technological applications. Thousands of CPs and MOF structures have been systematically produced in the last two decades, and the net result is considerable progress regarding the controlled synthesis and production of specific functionalities and tunable properties. MOFs and CPs have been explored in important fields such as biomedicine, sensing, gas storage, separation, adsorption, drug delivery, forensic science, and catalysis. MOFs are also regarded as an excellent platform for the production of light-emissive materials because they offer a well-defined chemical environment for emitter centers and their hybrid character renders them with a diversity of optical phenomenon uncommon in classical light-emitting materials. Among the plethora of luminescent CPs and MOFs already reported, those based on lanthanide ions, that is lanthanide-organic frameworks (Ln-MOFs), are the most promising because they combine fairly interesting structuresa and thermodynamic stability with well-known magnetic behavior and spectroscopic properties originating from the lanthanide ions.

elements.content: Most MOF applications reported hitherto are limited to bulk materials because, similarly to zeolites, MOF materials are insoluble in most solvents, therefore, hindering the preparation of thin films or their anchoring in substrates. More recently, several research groups have achieved significant progress in the deposition of MOFs onto substrates. For instance, Férey’s group has produced a flexible thin film of MIL-89 (Fe3OCl­(O2C–C4H4CO2), where O2C–C4H4CO2 is the muconate dicarboxylate ligand) by dip-coating on a silica substrate with high optical quality. The production of well-oriented thin films based on surface-attached MOF materials (SURMOFs) has gained significant importance for integrated device construction. Electrospinning has also been demonstrated to be valuable for encapsulating MOF materials and producing one-dimensional nanofibers. Despite the aforementioned potentialities, MOF-based miniaturized devices are extremely scarce because the control of the crystal size, position, and orientation on substrates remains a complex and difficult task. Innovative processing methods for MOFs and CPs may therefore be considered as the ultimate challenge for enhancing their high-technological industrial applicability. From this perspective, Falcaro and co-workers have developed several deposition protocols for MOF materials based on soft lithography. Alternatively, Terfort and co-workers developed a synthetic procedure that has enabled HKUST-1 ([Cu2(btc)2], btc = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate) and [Zn2(adc)2(dabco)2] (adc and dabco are 9,10-anthracenedicarboxylate and 1,4-diazabicyclo­[2,2,2]­octane, respectively) to be explored as a highly stable “ink”. This MOF inkjet printing is an attractive and advantageous methodology over conventional approaches, such as rapid processing rates, deposition in large areas without contamination, generation of minimal residues, and wide processability of computer-aided design (CAD) information. The inkjet printing method has been used to print macromolecules, nanoparticles, and therapeutic drugs. It is also used for the fabrication of flexible displays, solar cells, as catalysts, explosive sensors, transistors, data storage, and medical devices. Most recently, as a bid to enhance the security of documents and product authenticity and traceability, inkjet printing of luminescent molecules and inorganic nanocrystals has emerged as a low cost and customizable anticounterfeiting technology. On the basis of this new conception for MOFs and CP processing, we report herein an effective procedure for the fabrication of “inks” based on Ln-MOFs and their deposition onto flexible substrates with an off-the-shelf inkjet printer. This straightforward method permits the production of photoluminescent inks for invisible security labeling/encoding and supported catalysts, as will be disclosed in due course.
elements.clean_text: Most MOF applications reported hitherto are limited to bulk materials because, similarly to zeolites, MOF materials are insoluble in most solvents, therefore, hindering the preparation of thin films or their anchoring in substrates. More recently, several research groups have achieved significant progress in the deposition of MOFs onto substrates. For instance, Férey's group has produced a flexible thin film of MIL-89 (Fe3OCl(O2C-C4H4CO2), where O2C-C4H4CO2 is the muconate dicarboxylate ligand) by dip-coating on a silica substrate with high optical quality. The production of well-oriented thin films based on surface-attached MOF materials (SURMOFs) has gained significant importance for integrated device construction. Electrospinning has also been demonstrated to be valuable for encapsulating MOF materials and producing one-dimensional nanofibers. Despite the aforementioned potentialities, MOF-based miniaturized devices are extremely scarce because the control of the crystal size, position, and orientation on substrates remains a complex and difficult task. Innovative processing methods for MOFs and CPs may therefore be considered as the ultimate challenge for enhancing their high-technological industrial applicability. From this perspective, Falcaro and co-workers have developed several deposition protocols for MOF materials based on soft lithography. Alternatively, Terfort and co-workers developed a synthetic procedure that has enabled HKUST-1 ([Cu2(btc)2], btc = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate) and [Zn2(adc)2(dabco)2] (adc and dabco are 9,10-anthracenedicarboxylate and 1,4-diazabicyclo[2,2,2]octane, respectively) to be explored as a highly stable "ink". This MOF inkjet printing is an attractive and advantageous methodology over conventional approaches, such as rapid processing rates, deposition in large areas without contamination, generation of minimal residues, and wide processability of computer-aided design (CAD) information. The inkjet printing method has been used to print macromolecules, nanoparticles, and therapeutic drugs. It is also used for the fabrication of flexible displays, solar cells, as catalysts, explosive sensors, transistors, data storage, and medical devices. Most recently, as a bid to enhance the security of documents and product authenticity and traceability, inkjet printing of luminescent molecules and inorganic nanocrystals has emerged as a low cost and customizable anticounterfeiting technology. On the basis of this new conception for MOFs and CP processing, we report herein an effective procedure for the fabrication of "inks" based on Ln-MOFs and their deposition onto flexible substrates with an off-the-shelf inkjet printer. This straightforward method permits the production of photoluminescent inks for invisible security labeling/encoding and supported catalysts, as will be disclosed in due course.

elements.content: In this work, we have focused on the deposition of [Ln2(Mell)·6H2O] as inks, where Ln = Eu3+, Tb3+, Gd3+, or Nd3+ and Mell = mellitate, generating R-MOF, G-MOF, B-MOF, and NIR-MOF, respectively, in accordance with previous reports. One of the most interesting features of [Ln2(Mell)·6H2O] is the ease of fabrication of high photoluminescent crystals at room temperature. Recently, [Ln2(Mell)·6H2O] was successfully used as a platform for the production of white-light-emitting materials through layer-by-layer deposition of red, green, and blue emitters. The synthesis of [Ln2(Mell)·6H2O] materials was modified with the proposed rapid production of crystals. In the optimized synthetic approach, a mixture of mellitic acid (0.5 mmol), [Ln­(NO3)3·6H2O] (0.5 mmol), and H2O (5.0 mL) were kept under constant magnetic stirring for 5 min and then transferred to a 15 mL falcon tube. Rapid crystal nucleation was triggered by the slow addition of 1.5 mL (30% in volume) of organic solvents, such as ethanol, propanol, or methanol. Microcrystals were obtained in 53% yields. The slow diffusion of the precipitating agents results in large, well-formed crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction after only 5 min. The alcohol molecules added in the reaction mixture play an important role in Ln-MOF crystallization because they might completely or partially replace the solvent precursor around the building blocks, which induces a rapid crystal nucleation, as described elsewhere. The single-crystal and powder X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that R-, G-, and B-MOF materials, reported herein, are indeed isostructural and identical to those previously reported. Figures S1 and S2 depict the Ln-MOF structure along the b axis and their diffraction powder patterns.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

In this work, we have focused on the deposition of [Ln2(Mell)⋅6H2O] as inks, where Ln = Eu3+, Tb3+, Gd3+, or Nd3+ and Mell = mellitate, generating R-MOF, G-MOF, B-MOF, and NIR-MOF, respectively, in accordance with previous reports. One of the most interesting features of [Ln2(Mell)⋅6H2O] is the ease of fabrication of high photoluminescent crystals at room temperature. Recently, [Ln2(Mell)⋅6H2O] was successfully used as a platform for the production of white-light-emitting materials through layer-by-layer deposition of red, green, and blue emitters. The synthesis of [Ln2(Mell)⋅6H2O] materials was modified with the proposed rapid production of crystals. In the optimized synthetic approach, a mixture of mellitic acid (0.5 mmol), [Ln(NO3)3⋅6H2O] (0.5 mmol), and H2O (5.0 mL) were kept under constant magnetic stirring for 5 min and then transferred to a 15 mL falcon tube. Rapid crystal nucleation was triggered by the slow addition of 1.5 mL (30% in volume) of organic solvents, such as ethanol, propanol, or methanol. Microcrystals were obtained in 53% yields. The slow diffusion of the precipitating agents results in large, well-formed crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction after only 5 min. The alcohol molecules added in the reaction mixture play an important role in Ln-MOF crystallization because they might completely or partially replace the solvent precursor around the building blocks, which induces a rapid crystal nucleation, as described elsewhere. The single-crystal and powder X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that R-, G-, and B-MOF materials, reported herein, are indeed isostructural and identical to those previously reported. Figures S1 and S2 depict the Ln-MOF structure along the b axis and their diffraction powder patterns.

elements.content: Depositions of patterned Ln-MOF materials onto flexible substrates (transparency PET films of 3 M and paper sheets) were carried out with an unmodified mechanical type print head Inkjet Printer Cannon Pixma MP495 (Canon Inc., Japan). The ink solutions presented values of kinematic viscosities of 0.83 and 0.74 mm2 s–1 at 25 and 40 °C, which are similar to those used in conventional inks. The transparency PET foils were used as-made or after being washed 3 times with absolute ethanol (treated PET), aimed at removing the coated gel films that increase the adhesion of the inks. The removal of the coated gel was monitored via contact angle experiments and infrared spectroscopy. When the aqueous inks dropped on the pieces of the as-made and treated transparency foils, they have shown significant variations in their respective contact angles. As-made PET foils present a gradual reduction of 14.1 degrees (54.6 to 40.5°) in 300 s, whereas the contact angle for treated PET foils remains at 62.5° during the experiments. The higher contact angle presented by the treated plastic sheet indicates that the hydrophilic gel was completely removed from its surface. These results are corroborated by the IR spectra acquired for the PET substrates. The aqueous Ln-MOF “ink” solutions (3.0 mL) were placed in the color inkjet cartridge (10.00 mL), and a 90% ethanolic solution (precipitant agent) was added in the black cartridge. A resolution of 1200 dpi in a single printing cycle was used to deposit the Ln-MOF inks, and following the printed substrates, was dried for 5 min at room temperature. It is important to note that the small ink volume (2–10 pL) allows for fast drying of the ink solvent; furthermore, rapid crystal nucleation permits the production of patterned photoluminescent Ln-MOFs without the multiple “printing-drying” cycles, as described in previous reports. illustrates the processing used to print photoluminescent Ln-MOFs.
elements.clean_text: Depositions of patterned Ln-MOF materials onto flexible substrates (transparency PET films of 3 M and paper sheets) were carried out with an unmodified mechanical type print head Inkjet Printer Cannon Pixma MP495 (Canon Inc., Japan). The ink solutions presented values of kinematic viscosities of 0.83 and 0.74 mm2 s-1 at 25 and 40 °C, which are similar to those used in conventional inks. The transparency PET foils were used as-made or after being washed 3 times with absolute ethanol (treated PET), aimed at removing the coated gel films that increase the adhesion of the inks. The removal of the coated gel was monitored via contact angle experiments and infrared spectroscopy. When the aqueous inks dropped on the pieces of the as-made and treated transparency foils, they have shown significant variations in their respective contact angles. As-made PET foils present a gradual reduction of 14.1 degrees (54.6 to 40.5°) in 300 s, whereas the contact angle for treated PET foils remains at 62.5° during the experiments. The higher contact angle presented by the treated plastic sheet indicates that the hydrophilic gel was completely removed from its surface. These results are corroborated by the IR spectra acquired for the PET substrates. The aqueous Ln-MOF "ink" solutions (3.0 mL) were placed in the color inkjet cartridge (10.00 mL), and a 90% ethanolic solution (precipitant agent) was added in the black cartridge. A resolution of 1200 dpi in a single printing cycle was used to deposit the Ln-MOF inks, and following the printed substrates, was dried for 5 min at room temperature. It is important to note that the small ink volume (2-10 pL) allows for fast drying of the ink solvent; furthermore, rapid crystal nucleation permits the production of patterned photoluminescent Ln-MOFs without the multiple "printing-drying" cycles, as described in previous reports.  illustrates the processing used to print photoluminescent Ln-MOFs.

elements.clean_text: 1  Schematic Representation to Inkjet Print Ln-MOFs

elements.content: R- and G-MOF were printed individually onto polyethylene terephthalate (PET) foils to avoid the interference of the superposition of the ink halftone dots. Photoluminescence measurements were performed for Ln-MOF materials patterned onto treated (washed 3 times with absolute ethanol) and untreated transparency films and compared with those of Ln-MOF crystals. presents the emission spectra acquired at room temperature upon excitation at 254 nm for Ln-MOFs (a and b) and the printed designed patterns under ultraviolet irradiation (c and d). The emission spectra display narrow band characteristics of the Eu3+ 5 D 0 → 7 F J and Tb3+ 5 D 4 → 7 F J transitions. The relative intensities and the number of Stark components are dependent upon the extent in which the (2J+1) degeneracy is removed by the symmetry of the first coordination sphere; thus, they can be used as probe of symmetry sites in europium-based compounds. The as-prepared and the printed Eu-MOFs onto a treated substrate ((a)) show an identical spectral profiles, which is consistent with no structural alterations or significant defects caused by rapid crystallization, as previously described for other MOF materials. In contrast, the emission in Ln-MOF materials deposited onto untreated transparencies exhibit broader emission lines, which may be justified by structural alteration induced by the coated gel film. Table S1 collects the spectroscopic data for the Ln-MOF materials reported herein.

The emission spectra display narrow band characteristics of the Eu3+ 5 D 0  →  7 F  J  and Tb3+ 5 D 4  →  7 F  J  transitions. The relative intensities and the number of Stark components are dependent upon the extent in which the (2J+1) degeneracy is removed by the symmetry of the first coordination sphere; thus, they can be used as probe of symmetry sites in europium-based compounds. The as-prepared and the printed Eu-MOFs onto a treated substrate ((a)) show an identical spectral profiles, which is consistent with no structural alterations or significant defects caused by rapid crystallization, as previously described for other MOF materials. In contrast, the emission in Ln-MOF materials deposited onto untreated transparencies exhibit broader emission lines, which may be justified by structural alteration induced by the coated gel film. Table S1 collects the spectroscopic data for the Ln-MOF materials reported herein.

elements.content: (a and b) Emission spectra of R- and G-MOF inks. Solid red and green lines represents the emission spectra of the R- and G-MOF crystals, respectively, and solid black and blue lines denote the emission spectra of R- and G-MOF inks deposited onto treated and as-made transparency PET foils, respectively. (c and d) LnMOF inks deposited onto treated transparency PET substrates under UV light irradiation (λexc = 254 nm).
elements.clean_text: 1  (a and b) Emission spectra of R- and G-MOF inks. Solid red and green lines represents the emission spectra of the R- and G-MOF crystals, respectively, and solid black and blue lines denote the emission spectra of R- and G-MOF inks deposited onto treated and as-made transparency PET foils, respectively. (c and d) LnMOF inks deposited onto treated transparency PET substrates under UV light irradiation (λexc = 254 nm).

elements.content: The inkjet printing of Ln-MOFs were successfully tested not only in plastic substrates but also on several types of papers. shows the theoretical and experimental color tones and emission spectra upon excitation at 254 nm with the spectral barcode and CAD images designed simultaneously using Eu- and Tb-MOF inks.
elements.clean_text: The inkjet printing of Ln-MOFs were successfully tested not only in plastic substrates but also on several types of papers.  shows the theoretical and experimental color tones and emission spectra upon excitation at 254 nm with the spectral barcode and CAD images designed simultaneously using Eu- and Tb-MOF inks.

elements.content: (a) Theoretical/experimental RGB and CMYK color models and photoluminescent color tones (λexc = 254 nm) designed in a proportional ratio of R- and G-MOF. (b) Emission spectra of color gradients produced by R- and G-MOFs. (c) Luminescent barcode patterns obtained by integrated intensities of the Eu3+ and Tb3+ transitions. (d and e) Xylograph of the “Gibão” (public image) and Ln-MOF structure printed onto vegetal paper sheets under UV light irradiation. (f and g) Fragment of Hamlet by William Shakespeare printed onto vegetal paper codified with Ln-MOF under white and UV light irradiation, respectively. For demonstrating the perfect adhesion of Ln-MOF on the paper, the paper was first crumpled and then irradiated with white and UV light (λexc = 254 nm).
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Theoretical/experimental RGB and CMYK color models and photoluminescent color tones (λexc = 254 nm) designed in a proportional ratio of R- and G-MOF. (b) Emission spectra of color gradients produced by R- and G-MOFs. (c) Luminescent barcode patterns obtained by integrated intensities of the Eu3+ and Tb3+ transitions. (d and e) Xylograph of the "Gibão" (public image) and Ln-MOF structure printed onto vegetal paper sheets under UV light irradiation. (f and g) Fragment of Hamlet by William Shakespeare printed onto vegetal paper codified with Ln-MOF under white and UV light irradiation, respectively. For demonstrating the perfect adhesion of Ln-MOF on the paper, the paper was first crumpled and then irradiated with white and UV light (λexc = 254 nm).

elements.content:
The color gradient, exhibited in (a), was designed using R- and G-MOF inks ratios with RGB (CMYK, %) values of

1: 138, 239, 174 (29, 100, 29, 29);

2: 176, 236, 174 (65, 100, 29, 29);

3: 255, 255, 172 (100, 100, 29, 29);

4: 255, 231, 172 (100, 65, 29, 29);

5: 255, 157, 131 (100, 29, 29, 29).

The photoluminescent inks were systematically deposited by the halftone technique, which permits the production of a color gradient effect by the precise control of the size, distance, and superposition of the Ln-MOF “ink” dots. The additive luminescent colors obtained by superposition of the R- and G-MOF ink dots demonstrates good reproducibility when compared with the theoretical ones. Recent works have reported that the deposition of photoluminescent inks via the halftone method does not cause color quenching. This can be justified by the emitter centers that are inserted in distinct host domains. The emission spectra exhibited in (b) present simultaneous emission transitions typical of Tb3+ and Eu3+ ions whose amplitudes have presented a dependence with each ink dot quantity. Interestingly, luminescence investigations also demonstrate that different quantities of R- and G-MOF ink dots onto substrate surfaces can provide singular and discernible spectroscopic barcodes ((c)). Panels d and e in illustrate the Ln-MOF patterns deposited onto the paper substrate, demonstrating that the inkjet printing technique with Ln-MOF inks allows for the creation of complex hidden images useful for counterfeiting prevention. A fragment of Hamlet by William Shakespeare was overprinted in the same area of the “inks” with a conventional monochromatic laser printer (HP LaserJet 1022; (f and g)) to investigate the thermal stability and adherence of the patterned Ln-MOFs. The MOF printed regions present the same luminescence uniformity presented before the abrasive overprinting and crumpling processes.

In and are a sequence of images acquired for peel adhesion and abrasion resistance tests. shows images of G-MOF deposited onto vegetal paper substrates upon thermal treatment for 30 min at different temperatures.

elements.content: Sequence of images of a tape peel adhesion test acquired for the substrates under white and UV light irradiation (λexc = 254 nm) on (a) as-made transparency PET foils, (b) treated transparency PET foils, and (c) paper sheet.
elements.clean_text: 3  Sequence of images of a tape peel adhesion test acquired for the substrates under white and UV light irradiation (λexc = 254 nm) on (a) as-made transparency PET foils, (b) treated transparency PET foils, and (c) paper sheet.

elements.content: Sequence of images of an abrasion test performed with a rubber eraser for the substrates under white and UV light irradiation (λexc = 254 nm) on (a) as-made transparency PET foils, (b) treated transparency PET foils, and (c) vegetal paper.
elements.clean_text: 4  Sequence of images of an abrasion test performed with a rubber eraser for the substrates under white and UV light irradiation (λexc = 254 nm) on (a) as-made transparency PET foils, (b) treated transparency PET foils, and (c) vegetal paper.

elements.content: G-MOF printed onto vegetal paper substrates under (a) white and (b) UV light irradiation upon thermal treatment for 30 min at 60, 100, 150, and 200 °C.
elements.clean_text: 5   G-MOF printed onto vegetal paper substrates under (a) white and (b) UV light irradiation upon thermal treatment for 30 min at 60, 100, 150, and 200 °C.

elements.content: From the image sequences presented in and , it is evident that the Ln-MOF inks remain adhered onto the surface of the as-made transparency PET and vegetal paper sheets even after mechanical stress caused by tape peeling and rubber friction (See the movie of the abrasion test in the ), whereas they were easily removed from the treated transparency PET sheet. These results imply that the hydrophilic surface of the as-made PET and vegetal paper play important role in adhesion of the Ln-MOF crystals. The visual results of the thermal treatment as exposed in shows that even after 30 min under high temperatures the G-MOF ink printed onto the paper substrate presents with good stability, which is consistent with TGA curves presented in Figure S8. These results indicate that the Ln-MOF inks are promising for codification of documents and production of counterfeit items because they exhibit good stabilities and adhesion on hydrophilic substrate surface even upon exposure to stress caused by bending, peeling, abrasion, high temperatures of the fuser roller of laserjet printers (∼200 °C), and thermal treatments over long time periods.
elements.clean_text: From the image sequences presented in  and , it is evident that the Ln-MOF inks remain adhered onto the surface of the as-made transparency PET and vegetal paper sheets even after mechanical stress caused by tape peeling and rubber friction (See the movie of the abrasion test in the ), whereas they were easily removed from the treated transparency PET sheet. These results imply that the hydrophilic surface of the as-made PET and vegetal paper play important role in adhesion of the Ln-MOF crystals. The visual results of the thermal treatment as exposed in  shows that even after 30 min under high temperatures the G-MOF ink printed onto the paper substrate presents with good stability, which is consistent with TGA curves presented in Figure S8. These results indicate that the Ln-MOF inks are promising for codification of documents and production of counterfeit items because they exhibit good stabilities and adhesion on hydrophilic substrate surface even upon exposure to stress caused by bending, peeling, abrasion, high temperatures of the fuser roller of laserjet printers (~200 °C), and thermal treatments over long time periods.

elements.content: The photoluminescent colors associated with singular spectral fingerprints also make the Ln-MOF inks highly attractive for exploration as security elements in anticounterfeiting technologies. The emission spectra of B-MOF and NIR-MOF, displayed in , show a board band in the blue region typical of ligand-centered emissions. NIR-MOF still exhibits two emission bands centered at 1070 and 1350 nm, which can be attributed to 4 F 3/2 → 4 I 11/2 and 4 F 3/2 → 4 I 13/2 transitions of Nd3+ ions. NIR emission bands cannot be detected by the naked eye; hence, these signals can used as proof of authenticity because they are only identified spectroscopically. These results could make NIR-MOF inks potential candidates for the development of photoluminescent blue-NIR-emitting inks.
elements.clean_text: The photoluminescent colors associated with singular spectral fingerprints also make the Ln-MOF inks highly attractive for exploration as security elements in anticounterfeiting technologies. The emission spectra of B-MOF and NIR-MOF, displayed in , show a board band in the blue region typical of ligand-centered emissions. NIR-MOF still exhibits two emission bands centered at 1070 and 1350 nm, which can be attributed to 4 F  3/2   →  4 I  11/2  and 4 F  3/2   →  4 I  13/2  transitions of Nd3+ ions. NIR emission bands cannot be detected by the naked eye; hence, these signals can used as proof of authenticity because they are only identified spectroscopically. These results could make NIR-MOF inks potential candidates for the development of photoluminescent blue-NIR-emitting inks.

elements.content: (a and b) Photoluminescence spectra of B-MOF and NIR-MOF. The excitation spectra were acquired at room temperature while monitoring the emissions of B-MOF and NIR-MOF at 450 and 437 nm. (c) Photoluminescence spectra of NIR-MOF. The excitation spectrum was obtained at room temperature while monitoring the transition of 4 F 3/2 → 4 I 11/2 at 1070 nm.
elements.clean_text: 6  (a and b) Photoluminescence spectra of B-MOF and NIR-MOF. The excitation spectra were acquired at room temperature while monitoring the emissions of B-MOF and NIR-MOF at 450 and 437 nm. (c) Photoluminescence spectra of NIR-MOF. The excitation spectrum was obtained at room temperature while monitoring the transition of 4 F  3/2   →  4 I  11/2  at 1070 nm.

elements.content: To evaluate the reproduction of invisible full color images, we placed R-, G-, and NIR-MOFs in cyan, magenta, and yellow partitions of a tricolor, respectively. presents the emission spectra and theoretical/experimental photoluminescent color tones obtained under excitation at 254 nm for the superposed R-, G-, and NIR-MOF inks. The spectra were acquired at room temperature upon excitation at 254 nm. The emission spectra, exhibited in (a), display broad bands centered at around 430 nm of the ligand emission of NIR-MOF. The narrow band between 480 and 720 nm can be assigned to the 5 D 0 → 7 F J and 5 D 4 → 7 F J transitions of the Eu3+ and Tb3+ ions. (b) shows the emission lines of the Nd3+ cations in the NIR region. The paper surface covered with R-, G-, and NIR-MOFs presents a poor color reproducibility that can be justified by the low blue emission intensity of NIR-MOF and irregular distributions of the microcrystals onto the substrate surfaces.
elements.clean_text: To evaluate the reproduction of invisible full color images, we placed R-, G-, and NIR-MOFs in cyan, magenta, and yellow partitions of a tricolor, respectively.  presents the emission spectra and theoretical/experimental photoluminescent color tones obtained under excitation at 254 nm for the superposed R-, G-, and NIR-MOF inks. The spectra were acquired at room temperature upon excitation at 254 nm. The emission spectra, exhibited in (a), display broad bands centered at around 430 nm of the ligand emission of NIR-MOF. The narrow band between 480 and 720 nm can be assigned to the 5 D 0  →  7 F  J  and 5 D 4  →  7 F  J  transitions of the Eu3+ and Tb3+ ions. (b) shows the emission lines of the Nd3+ cations in the NIR region. The paper surface covered with R-, G-, and NIR-MOFs presents a poor color reproducibility that can be justified by the low blue emission intensity of NIR-MOF and irregular distributions of the microcrystals onto the substrate surfaces.

elements.content: (a and b) Emission spectra in visible and near-infrared regions produced by superposition of the R-, G-, and NIR-MOF photoluminescent inks. (c and d) RGB (λexc = 254 nm) and CMYK color models designed in a proportional ratio of the three luminescent inks. Note: numbers 1–5 were used to correlate the emission spectra and the colors produced.

elements.content: (a and b) SEM images of R-MOF printed onto treated and untreated PET foils. (c and d) SEM images of G-MOF deposited on a vegetal paper substrate. (e and f): AFM images of R-MOF printed on a treated transparent PET surface.
elements.clean_text: 8  (a and b) SEM images of R-MOF printed onto treated and untreated PET foils. (c and d) SEM images of G-MOF deposited on a vegetal paper substrate. (e and f): AFM images of R-MOF printed on a treated transparent PET surface.

elements.content: SEM and AFM images of printed substrates in a single printing cycle are shown in . The SEM images obtained for plastic and paper substrates show that the surface is partially covered with Ln-MOFs microcrystals with board size distributions (0.4–8.0 μm) after a single printing cycle. Atomic force microscopy (AFM) in noncontact mode was used to obtain the topographic images recorded with a silicon tip (radius <5 nm). The AFM images of Ln-MOFs are printed on a treated transparent PET surface ((e)) and on an untreated transparent PET surface ((f)). The images show that the G-MOF crystal is homogeneous when printed on the treated PET surface. However, when both R-MOFs and G-MOFs are printed on an untreated PET surface, the MOF crystals are embedded in the gel, and the grains are more separated from each other. This effect could be related to the broader emission lines seen in (a and b).
elements.clean_text: SEM and AFM images of printed substrates in a single printing cycle are shown in . The SEM images obtained for plastic and paper substrates show that the surface is partially covered with Ln-MOFs microcrystals with board size distributions (0.4-8.0 μm) after a single printing cycle. Atomic force microscopy (AFM) in noncontact mode was used to obtain the topographic images recorded with a silicon tip (radius <5 nm). The AFM images of Ln-MOFs are printed on a treated transparent PET surface ((e)) and on an untreated transparent PET surface ((f)). The images show that the G-MOF crystal is homogeneous when printed on the treated PET surface. However, when both R-MOFs and G-MOFs are printed on an untreated PET surface, the MOF crystals are embedded in the gel, and the grains are more separated from each other. This effect could be related to the broader emission lines seen in (a and b).

elements.content: In summary, we have demonstrated a facile, low-cost, and time-efficient strategy for the positioning of photoluminescent Ln-MOFs on flexible substrates (paper and plastic foils) using a conventional commercially available inkjet printer. The spatial control over the positioning of the MOF and CPs is still a challenging task, and this work advances this amazing new technology. This work also opens several possibilities for the development of multifunctional miniaturized platforms based on Ln-MOF materials and technological applications, such as optical devices (e.g., lab-on-a-chip), proof of authenticity for official documents (forensic applications), sensing, and, as will be evaluated and disclosed elsewhere, catalysts.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we have demonstrated a facile, low-cost, and time-efficient strategy for the positioning of photoluminescent Ln-MOFs on flexible substrates (paper and plastic foils) using a conventional commercially available inkjet printer. The spatial control over the positioning of the MOF and CPs is still a challenging task, and this work advances this amazing new technology. This work also opens several possibilities for the development of multifunctional miniaturized platforms based on Ln-MOF materials and technological applications, such as optical devices (e.g., lab-on-a-chip), proof of authenticity for official documents (forensic applications), sensing, and, as will be evaluated and disclosed elsewhere, catalysts.

cln_elements.content: (a and b) Emission spectra of R- and G-MOF inks. Solid red and green lines represents the emission spectra of the R- and G-MOF crystals, respectively, and solid black and blue lines denote the emission spectra of R- and G-MOF inks deposited onto treated and as-made transparency PET foils, respectively. (c and d) LnMOF inks deposited onto treated transparency PET substrates under UV light irradiation (λexc = 254 nm).
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  (a and b) Emission spectra of R- and G-MOF inks. Solid red and green lines represents the emission spectra of the R- and G-MOF crystals, respectively, and solid black and blue lines denote the emission spectra of R- and G-MOF inks deposited onto treated and as-made transparency PET foils, respectively. cln_elements.content: (a) Theoretical/experimental RGB and CMYK color models and photoluminescent color tones (λexc = 254 nm) designed in a proportional ratio of R- and G-MOF. (b) Emission spectra of color gradients produced by R- and G-MOFs. (c) Luminescent barcode patterns obtained by integrated intensities of the Eu3+ and Tb3+ transitions. (d and e) Xylograph of the “Gibão” (public image) and Ln-MOF structure printed onto vegetal paper sheets under UV light irradiation. (f and g) Fragment of Hamlet by William Shakespeare printed onto vegetal paper codified with Ln-MOF under white and UV light irradiation, respectively. For demonstrating the perfect adhesion of Ln-MOF on the paper, the paper was first crumpled and then irradiated with white and UV light (λexc = 254 nm).
